13 MOTIONS TO DISMISS SECOND
AMENDED COMPLAINT
JULIE L. MEYERS, et al.,
14
Defendants.
15
16
17 This matter comes before the Court on Defenda ntsโ motions to dismiss Plaintiffsโ Second
18 Amended Complaint (โSACโ).  The m atter has been fully briefed a nd argued.  Having carefully
19 considered the papers submitted and the argument of counsel, the Court grants in part and denies in
20 part Defendantsโ motions.
21 I.
22 BACKGROUND
23 The facts of this case are well known to the parties.  Therefore, the Court sets forth only those
24 facts relevant to the present motion.  
25 Plaintiffs have filed suit alleging serious overcrowding at the San Diego Correctional Facility
26 (SDCF) dating back to at least November 2004.  Plaintiffs include Isaac Kigondu Kiniti, Jose Morales-
27 Vargas, Sylvester Owino, Hernan Ismael Delgado, and Any Castro.  Of these Plaintiffs, only Kiniti
28 and Owino currently are detained  at the SDCF.  The rem aining Plaintiffs have been rem oved or
- 1 -
05cv1013

1 transferred: Castro was deported to Honduras on February 1, 2007, Morales-Vargas was deported to
2 Guatemala on May 11, 2007, and Delgado was transferred from SDCF to El Centro, California on
3 February 16, 2007.  Based on changes that Defendanst made to the housing conditions challenged by
4 Plaintiffs in this lawsuit and the relocation of  Plaintiffs Castro, Morales-Vargas and Delgado,
5 Defendants move to dismiss the SAC as moot.  
6 The SAC alleges a violation of the Due Process Clause under the Fifth Amendment of the
7 United States Constitution due to โchronic and severe overcrowding.โ  It alleges:
8 Defendantsโ policies, practices, acts, and omissions with respect to chronic and
severe overcrowding at SDCF โ including but not limited to the triple-celling of
9 immigration detainees and the housing of additional detainees in common day
room spaces โ deprive plaintiffs of adequate shelter, reasonable safety, and basic
10 human needs, and place them at unreasonable, continuing and foreseeable risk
of, inter alia, increased violence, illness, mental suffering, and deteriorating
11 health.
12 SAC at ยถ 111.  According to the SAC, โtriple-celling oโccurs when three detainees are housed in a cell
13 designed for two.  When this happens, a plastic โboatโ containing a thin sleeping mat is placed on the
14 floor for the third detainee to sleep on.  Id. at ยถ 54.  Plaintiffs allege this practice affects about 675 of
15 the approximately 1000 detainees at SDCF. I d. at ยถ2.  In addition to triple-celling, some detainees are
16 housed in โmakeshift beds placed in the common day room space.โ Id. at ยถ 41.  Holding cells and
17 administrative segregation units are also overcrowded.   Id. at ยถยถ 75-79.  โA typical holding cellโ
18 provides just enough space for 12 detainees to sleepi n a row on the floor, side-by-side, touching each
19 other, โlike sardines.โ  Id. at ยถ76.  Administrative segregation is used to house โoverflow detaineesโ
20 and โdetainees who refuse to be triple-celled.โ I d. at ยถ 78.  Segregated detainees are confined in their
21 cells for 23 to 24 hours per day and are required to eat all meals in their cells. Id. at ยถ 79.  They are
22 provided only one hour out-of-cell fore xercise, five days per week, in a small cement yard surrounded
23 by a chainlink fence.  Id.
24 Based upon these allegations, the SAC seeks j udgment: (1) declaring that such policies  
25 โviolate plaintiffsโ rights under the Constitution,โ and (2) permanently enjoining Defendants โfrom
26 subjecting plaintiffs to the unconstitutional conditions.โ  Id., โPrayer for Reliefโ (c)(d). 
27 / / /
28 / / /
- 2 -
05cv1013

1 II. 
2 LEGAL STANDARD
3 A. 12(b)(1)
4 โBecause standing and mootness both pertain to a federal courtโs subject-matter jurisdiction
5 under Article III, they are properly raised in a motion to dismiss under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure
6 12(b)(1), not Rule 12(b)(6).โ 1White v. Lee, 227 F.3d 1214, 1242 (9th Cir. 2000) (citations omitted).
7 A rule 12(b)(1) challenge can be either facial or factual.  Id.  With a facial attack, a defendant may
8 argue the allegations on the face of the com plaint are insufficient to show federal subject m atter
9 jurisdiction.  See Warren v. Fox Family Wordwide, Inc,. 328 F.3d 1136, 1139 (9th Cir. 2003).  As with
10 a Rule 12(b)(6) motion, the court must treat the allegations in the complaint as true and draw all
11 inferences in favor of the plaintiff.  See Gould v. U.S., 220 F.3d 169, 176 (3rd Cir. 2000).  W ith a
12 factual attack, however, the moving party โdisputes the truth of the allegations that, by themselves,
13 would otherwise invoke federal jurisdiction.โ  Safe Air For Everyone v. Meyer, 373 F.3d 1035, 1039
14 (9th Cir. 2004).  In reviewing the challenge, the court may consider  and weigh evidence outside the
15 pleadings without converting the motion into a motion for summary judgment.  Id. (citations omitted);
16 Roberts v. Corrothers, 812 F.2d 1173, 1177 (9th Cir. 1987).   The Court need not presum e the
17 truthfulness of the plaintiffโs allegations. I d.  Once the moving party has presented affidavits or other
18 evidence supporting its motion, the non-moving party must furnish evidence necessary to satisfy its
19 burden of establishing subject matter jurisdiction.  Id. 
20 B. Standing -- Mootness
21 โThe jurisdiction of federal courts depends on the existence of a โcase or controversyโ under
22 Article III of the Constitution.โ  GTE California, Inc. v. Federal Communications Commโn, 39 F.3d
23 940, 945 (9th Cir. 1994).  An actual controversy must exist at every stage of the litigation.  See Roe
24 v. Wade, 410 U.S. 113, 125 (1973).  โIn general a case becomes moot โwhen the issues presented are
25
26 1 Two motions are at issue: one filed by Defendants Corrections Corporation of America, Inc.
(โCCAโ), Easterling and Howard, and the other by the remaining defendants.  Both motions challenge
27 subject matter jurisdiction based on mootness.  CCA, Easterling and Howard move to dismiss under
Rule 12(b)(6), while the remaining defendants move to dismiss under Rule 12(b)(1).  Because
28 mootness questions concern subject matter jurisdiction, the Court will construe the 12(b)(6) motion
as a 12(b)(1) motion. 
- 3 -
05cv1013

1 no longer โliveโ or the parties lack a leglaly cognizable interest in the outcome.โ  Murphy v. Hunt, 455
2 U.S. 478, 481 (1982).  In other words, a case is moot if the issues presented are no longer of any direct
3 concern to the parties, and the Court would merely be resolving a hypothetical question.  Where a
4 defendant  asserts the โquestion sought to be a djudicated  has been m ooted  by subsequent
5 developments,โ Flast v. Cohen, 392 U.S. 83, 96 (1968), it bears the burden of proof.  Mangual v.
6 Rotger-Sabat, 317 F.3d 45, 60 (1st Cir. 2003) (โ[T]he burden of establishing mootness rests squarely
7 on the party raising it.โ). 
8 III. 
9 DISCUSSION
10 Defendants mount a factual jurisdictional challenge, contending (1) Morales-Vargas, Delgado
11 and Castroโs claims are moot because they are no longer detained at SDCF; and (2) although Kiniti
12 and Owino remain at the facility, their claim s are moot because the conditions they challenge  no
13 longer exist.
14 A. Morales-Vargas, Delgado and Castro
15 Defendants argue the claim s of Morales-Vargas, Delgado and Castro are m oot because
16 Morales-Vargas and Castro have been deported, and Delgado was transferred to another facility.  CCA
17 Mot. to Dismiss, at 6-7.  A case โbecomes moot โwhen the issues presented are no longer โliveโ or the
18 parties lack a legally cognizable interest in the outcome.โ  Murphy, 455 U.S. at 481.  Because Castro
19 and Morales-Vargas have been deported, neither ha s a cognizable interest in the outcom e of this
20 litigation.  Plaintiffs do not argue otherwise.  Accordingly, their claims are dismissed. 
21 With respect to Delgado, Plaintiffs argue his claim falls under the โcapable of repetition, yet
22 evading reviewโ exception to the mootness doctrine.  Id. at 13.  This exception provides that a named
23 plaintiff may litigate class certification even though he has no personal stake in the outcome of the
24 litigation.  U.S. Parole Commission v. Geraghty, 445 U.S. 388, 398 (1980).  The exception applies
25 where the named plaintiff had a personal stake at the outset of the litigation, and the claim may arise
26 again with respect to that plaintiff. I d.  Here, Plaintiffs have established a reasonable expectation that
27 Delgado may be transferred back to SDCF.  Delgado remains in ICE custody and is being held at the
28 El Centro Service Processing Center.  It is not uncommon for detainees to be transferred back and
- 4 -
05cv1013

1 forth between SDCF and El Centro.  Kiniti Decl. ยถ 9.  Indeed, Plaintiff Kiniti and others have been
2 transferred between the two facilities on several occasions.   Id. ยถยถ 2-5.  Delgado has therefore
3 demonstrated that his claim is โcapable of repetition, yet evading review.โ  The motion is denied as
4 to Delgado.
5 B. Kiniti and Owino
6 The SAC alleges Plaintiffs are subject to a condition of chronic overcrowding arising from:
7 (1) triple-celling; (2) the housing of some detainees in makeshift beds in common day room space;
8 (3) overcrowded holding cells; and (4) the housing  of overflow detainees in an adm inistrative
9 segregation unit.  ICE Mot. to Dismiss, at 3.  
10 Defendants contend Kiniti and Owinoโs claims are moot because the conditions they challenge
11 no longer exist and are unlikely to recur.  In suppotr, Defendants submit declarations from Easterling
12 and Timothy L. Perry, Deputy Assistant Director  for Detention Managem ent for the Office of
13 Detention and Removal Operations.  Both a ffiants have informed the Court that SDCF has been
14 operating below capacity since January 28, 2007, andth e allegedly wrongful conduct no longer exists.
15 On January 27, 2007, shortly after the SAC was filed,I CE directed CCA to prepare 104 detainees for
16 deportation and/or transfer to other facilities.  Easterling Decl., at ยถ 10.  That discharge negated the
17 need to continue any of the practices challenged in the SAC.  Id. at ยถ 11.  Thus, no ICE detainees are
18 currently triple celled; SDCF โhas refraine d from using โboatsโ since January 28, 2007;โ no
19 immigration detainees have been held in a holdnig cell for longer than 12 hours; and โno immigration
20 pod, administrative segregation unit or ICE holding cell has exceeded capacity.โ  Easterling Decl. at
21 ยถ 28; Perry Decl. at ยถยถ 19-20; 25-26.  In addition, as of May 1, 2007, only 11 detainees were housed
22 in the common day room, and these assignments are โtemporary,โ usually not exceeding 24 hours
23 while appropriate housing is being determined. Perry Decl. At ยถยถ 22 and 23; Easterling Decl., ยถ 31.
24 Perry states, given population le vels between 575 and 692 detainees per day, that he has โno
25 reasonable expectationโ that any of the alleged conduct will recur.  Perry Decl., at ยถยถ 17, 26. 
26 Defendants, however, have failed to satisfy their heavy burden of dem onstrating it is
27 โabsolutely clear that the allegedly wrongful conduct could not reasonably be expected to recur.โ
28 Carlton v. United Academics-AAUP/AFT/APEA AFL-CIO , 265 F.3d 778, 786 (9th Cir. 2001)
- 5 -
05cv1013

1 (emphasis in original).  Defendantsโ burden of persuasion is โstringent.โ  Friends of the Earth, Inc.v.
2 Laidlaw Environmental Services (TOC), Inc., 528 U.S. 167, 189 (2000).  This heavy burden is met
3 where, for example, a defendant acknowledges inw  riting that the challenged conduct is unlawful and
4 provides assurances the offending conduct will not be repeated. S ee Forest Guardians v. U.S. Forest
5 Serv., 329 F.3d 1089, 1095 (9th Cir. 2003) (It is โunreasonable to thinkโ defendant โwould return to
6 conduct it has admitted to this court is constitutionally deficient.โ). S ee also Carlton, 265 F.3d at 780
7 (โIt is unreasonable to think that the Union would resort to conduct that it had adimtted in writing was
8 constitutionally deficient and had attempted to correct ...โ).  
9 In contrast, Defendants here have not acknow ledged, in writing or otherwise, that the
10 challenged conduct is wrong or that overcrowding eve rwas a problem at SDCF.  Nor have they stated
11 they would not reinstate the practices in question.  In fact, Defendants dispute whether triple-celling
12 is  unconstitutional and maintain such practices do โnot result in a violation of Plaintiffsโ civil rights.โ
13 CCA Mot. to Dismiss, at 5, n.1.  Under these circum stances, Defendantsโ representation that no
14 detainees are currently being triple-celled and they don ot expect such to recur, is insufficient to render
15 the controversy moot.  
16 IV. 
17 CONCLUSION
18 Defendantsโ motions to dismiss the SAC are granted in part and denied in part as set forth
19 above.  
20 IT IS SO ORDERED.
21 DATED:  June 21, 2007
22
23 HON. DANA M. SABRAW
United States District Judge

Judge Lewis

documents.title: Order Granting Motion For Class Certification
documents.text:
1
2
3
4
5
6
7
8 UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
9 SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA
10
11 ISAAC KIGONDU KINITI, CASE NO. 05cv1013 DMS (PCL)
12 Plaintiff, ORDER GRANTING MOTION
vs. FOR CLASS CERTIFICATION
13
JULIE L. MEYERS, et al.,
14
Defendants.
15
16 This matter comes before the Court on Plaintiffsโ motion for class certification.  Defendants
17 have submitted oppositions to the motion, and Plaintiffs have submitted a reply.  Additionally, at oral
18 argument on July 6, 2007, the Court ordered the partise to submit supplemental briefing regarding the
19 applicability of 8 U.S.C. ยง 1252(f)(1 ) and whether differences in the im migration status of class
20 members present a barrier to class certification.  Having considered the papers submitted, including
21 the supplemental briefing and the arguments of counsel, the Court GRANTS Plaintiffsโ motion for
22 class certification.
23 I.
24 BACKGROUND
25 The facts of this case are well known to the partise.  Therefore, the Court sets forth only those
26 facts relevant to the present motion.  Plaintiffs have filed suit alleging serious overcrowding at the San
27 Diego Correctional Facility (SDCF) dating back to at least November 2004.  Plaintiffs include Isaac
28 Kigondu Kiniti, Sylvester Owino, and Hernan Ismael Delgado.  Delgado, however, was transferred
- 1 -
05cv1013

1 from SDCF to El Centro, California on February 16, 2007, where he is currently housed. 
2 The SAC alleges a violation of the Due Pr ocess Clause under the Fifth Amendment of the
3 United States Constitution due to โchronic and severe overcrowding.โ  It alleges:
4 Defendantsโ policies, practices, acts, and omissions with respect to chronic and
severe overcrowding at SDCF โ including but not limited to the triple-celling of
5 immigration detainees and the housing of additional detainees in common day
room spaces โ deprive plaintiffs of adequate shelter, reasonable safety, and basic
6 human needs, and place them at unreasonable, continuing and foreseeable risk
of, inter alia, increased violence, illness, m ental suffering, and deteriorating
7 health.
8 SAC at ยถ 111.  According to the SAC, โtriple-celling โoccurs when three detainees are housed in a cell
9 designed for two.  When this happens, a plastic โboatโ containing a thin sleeping mat is placed on the
10 floor for the third detainee to sleep on.  Id. at ยถ 54.  Plaintiffs allege this practice affects about 675 of
11 the approximately 1000 detainees at SDCF. I d. at ยถ2.  In addition to triple-celling, some detainees are
12 housed in โmakeshift beds placed in the common day room space.โ Id. at ยถ 41.  Holding cells and
13 administrative segregation units are also overcrowded.   Id. at ยถยถ 75-79.  โA typical holding cellโ
14 provides just enough space for 12 detainees to sleep side-by-side on the floor โlike sardines.โ  Id. at
15 ยถ76.  Administrative segregation is used to house โoverflow detaineesโ and โdetainees who refuse to
16 be triple-celled.โ  Id. at ยถ 78.  Segregated detainees are confined in their cells for 23 to 24 hours per
17 day and are required to eat all meals in their cells. Id. at ยถ 79.  They are provided only one hour out-of-
18 cell for exercise, five days per week, in a small cement yard surrounded by a chainlink fence.  Id.
19 Based upon these allegations, the SAC seeks judgm ent: (1) declaring that such policies
20 โviolate plaintiffsโ rights under the Constitution,โ and (2) enjoining Defendants โfrom  subjecting
21 plaintiffs to the unconstitutional conditions.โ  Id., โPrayer for Reliefโ (c)(d). 
22 II.
23 LEGAL STANDARDS
24 A. Standing and Ripeness
25 The requirements of Article III standing are well-etsablished: A plaintiff must show: (1) he has
26 suffered an โinjury in factโ that is (a) concrete and particularized, and (b) actual or im minent, not
27 conjectural or hypothetical; (2) the injury is fairly traceable to the challenged action of the defendant;
28 and (3) it is likely, as opposed to merely speculative, that the injury will be redressed by a favorable
- 2 -
05cv1013

1 decision.  Sacks v. Office of Foreign Assets Contro,l 466 F.3d 764, 771 (9th Cir. 2006) (citingF riends
2 of the Earth, Inc. v. Laidl aw Envtl. Servs. (TOC), Inc., 528 U.S. 167, 180-81 (2000)).  Article III
3 standing requires the plaintiff to establish standingf or each and every challenge and form of relief he
4 seeks.  Id.  
5 The โ[r]ipeness doctrine protects against premature adjudication of suits in which declaratory
6 relief is sought,โ Hodgers-Durgin v. de la Vina, 199 F.3d 1037, 1044 (9th Cir. 1999) (en banc), in
7 order to prevent โentanglement in theoretical or abstract disagreements that do not yet have a concrete
8 impact on the parties.โ  18 Unnamed โJohn Smithโ Prisoners v. Meese, 871 F.2d 881, 883 (9th Cir.
9 1989).  โIn โmeasuring whether the litigant has asserted an injury that is real and concrete rather than
10 speculative and hypothetical, the ripeness injury merges almost completely with standing.โโ  Scott v.
11 Pasadena Unified School Dist., 306 F.3d 646, 662 (9th Cir. 2002).  โAs a prudential matter, we will
12 not consider a claim to be ripe for judicial resolution โif it rests upon contingent future events that may
13 not occur as anticipated, or indeed may not occur at all.โโ  Id.   
14 B.  Class Certification
15 A district court may certify a class only if: โ(1) the class is so numerous that joinder of all
16 members is impracticable; (2) there are questions of law and fact common to the class; (3) the claims
17 or defenses of the representative parties are typical of the claims or defenses of the class; and (4) the
18 representative parties will fairly and adequately protect the interests of the class.โ  Dukes v. Wal-Mart,
19 Inc., 474 F.3d 1214, 1224 (9th Cir. 2007) (citing Fed.R.Civ.P. 23(a)).  โThe district court must also
20 find that at least one of the following three conditions are satisfied: (1) the prosecution of separate
21 actions would create a risk of: (a) inconsistent ovr arying adjudications or (b) individual adjudications
22 dispositive of the interests of other members not a party to those adjudications; (2) the party opposing
23 the class has acted or refused to act on grounds generally applicable to the class; or (3) the questions
24 of law or fact common to the members of the class predominate over any questions affecting only
25 individual members, and a class action is superior to other available methods for the fair and efficient
26 adjudication of the controversy.โ I d. (citing Fed.R.Civ.P. 23(b)).  Thep arty seeking certification bears
27 the burden of showing that each of the four requirements of Rule 23(a) and at least one requirement
28 of Rule 23(b) have been met.  Id.
- 3 -
05cv1013

1 III. 
2 DISCUSSION
3 Defendants argue (1) Plaintiffs lack standing to seek injunctive relief, (Federal Defendants
4 Opposition (โFed. Opp.โ) at 3; CCA Defendants Opposition (โCCA Opp.โ) at 17); (2) the claims of
5 โunnamed, future detaineesโ are not yet ripe, (Fed.  Opp. at 4); and (3) Plaintiffs have not m et the
6 requirements of Rule 23.  At oral argument, the Federal Defendants argued for the first time that 8
7 U.S.C. ยง 1252(f)(1) bars this case from proceeding as an injunctive class action and requested that the
8 Court permit supplemental briefing on this issue.  The CCA Defendants also requested that they be
9 allowed to further brief the issue whether the difference in immigration status between class members
10 bars class certification.  These issues are addressed below.
11 A. Standing
12 Defendants claim Plaintiffs lack standing because they have not โdemonstrate[d] actual or
13 potential harm arising out of [D]efendantsโ alleged conduct.โ  Fed. Opp. at 3.  Further, Defendants
14 contend Plaintiffs cannot show the alleged harm โwill be repeated.โ  Id. at 3-4. 
15 In order to assert a claim on behalf of a class ,the named Plaintiffs must demonstrate they have
16 personally sustained an injury which results from a challenged statute or government conduct.  See
17 Armstrong v. Davis, 275 F.3d 849, 860 (9th Cir. 2001).  Cont rary to Defendantsโ contention, the
18 named Plaintiffs have sufficiently demonstrated at this stage of the litigation that they have standing.
19 Kiniti and Owino declare they were repeatedly triple-celled while detained at SDCF, forced to sleep
20 in a โboatโ on the floor of the cell, observed physical al tercations as a result of the crowded
21 conditions, and experienced unsanitary conditions (including being โsprayed with urineโ while
22 sleeping on a โboatโ).  Reply, Ex. I, Owino Decl.; Kiniti Decl. ISO Opp. Mt. to Dis. SAC.  Plaintiff
23 Delgado alleged in the SAC he was triple-celled for the majority of his 27 months at SDCF and slept
24 on a โboatโ for more than six months.  SAC at ยถ 18.  As ar eview of the substantive merits of the case
25 at this stage in the litigation is inappropriate, the Court will not evaluate the veracity of the claimed
26 injuries at this time.  See Blackie v. Barrack, 524 F.2d 891, 901 n. 17 (9th Cir. 1975).  The detailed
27 allegations of the SAC and supporting declarations aer sufficient to establish that the named Plaintiffs
28 (a) have sustained injuries as result of the alleged violations, and (b) have a personal stake in the
- 4 -
05cv1013

1 action.
2 In support of their argument that Plaintiffs lack standing to seek injunctive relief, Defendants
3 cite City of Los Angeles v. Lyons, 461 U.S. 95 (1983).  In that case, Lyons was stopped at 2 a.m. by
4 Los Angeles police officers based on a burnt out taillight.  He wass ubsequently choked by the police,
5 causing him to lose consciousness and suffer perm anent damage to his larynx.  Lyons sought an
6 injunction barring the Los Angeles Police Department from using chokeholds except in certain limited
7 circumstances.  The Court held that in the absence of a realistic threat of future injury, Lyons could
8 not โdemonstrate a case or controversy with the City that would justify the injunctive relief sought.โ
9 Id. at 105. 
10 The Ninth Circuit, however, has distinguishedL yons from cases in which, as here, the plaintiff
11 โdid nothing illegal to promptโ the defendantโs conduct.   Hodgers-Durgin, 199 F.3d at 1041.  In
12 Hodgers-Durkin, the court affirmed the district courtโs finding that the plaintiffs had standing to seek
13 injunctive relief.  The plaintiffs, motorists who had been stopped by Border Patrol agents, alleged the
14 defendant engaged in a practice of routinely stopping motorists without reasonable suspicion.  In
15 affirming the district court, the Ninth Circuit distinguished Lyons, noting that the Lyons Court itself
16 โsuggested that the s top was prompted by Lyonsโ misconduct, holding that Lyons had failed to
17 โdemonstrate a case or controversyโ because he had not established a โreal and immediate threat that
18 he would again be stopped  for a traffic violation, or for any other offense .โโ  Id.  (emphasis in
19 original.)  The court further observed that inS pencer v. Kemna, 523 U.S. 1 (1998), the Supreme Court
20 characterized the denial of standing in Lyons โas having been based on the plaintiffโs ability to avoid
21 engaging in illegal conduct.โ  Hodgers-Durgin, 199 F.3d at 1041.  Applying the Suprem e Courtโs
22 interpretation of Lyons, the Ninth Circuit concluded the motorists had standing to challenge the Border
23 Patrolโs practice.  The court explained: โUnlike in  Lyons, in this case it is uncontested that both
24 plaintiffs engaged in entirely innocent conduct,โ and, further, that โin this case there is no string of
25 contingencies necessary to produce an injury.โ  Id. at 1041-2.  
26 Similarly, Plaintiffs here have no control overw  hen or whether Defendants will resume triple-
27 celling.  Rather, the allegations in the SAC, coupled with the evidence presented thus far, indicate
28 Defendants โhave repeatedly engaged in the injurious acts in the pastn, da there is sufficient possibility
- 5 -
05cv1013

1 that they will engage in them  in the near f uture to satisfy the realistic repetition requirem ent.โ
2 Armstrong, 275 F.3d at 861.  The SAC alleges, and Defendants do not dispute, that  Defendants
3 engaged in triple-celling for several years.  SAC ยถ 2.  Moreover, Defendants continue to assert now
4 as in past  motions that triple-celling is not unconstitutional.  Fed. Opp. at 9; CCA Mot. to Dis. at 5,
5 n.1; Def. Opp. to Mt. Leave to Amend. at 30.  In their motions to dismiss, Defendants acknowledge
6 that they continue to engage in som e of the alleged conduct, including housing detainees in the
7 common day room, albeit sporadically.  Perry Decl. ISO Mt. to Dis. at ยถ 22.  Further, even though
8 triple-celling no longer takes place at SDCF, Defe ndants have failed to assure this Court that the
9 practice will not resume in the future.  June 21, 2007 Order at 6.  Given Defendantsโ position that
10 triple-celling is not unconstitutional (an issue that willb e addressed on the merits at a later time in this
11 litigation), as well as the adm itted history of triple-celling, the Cour t concludes Plaintiffs have
12 standing to seek injunctive relief.
13 B. Ripeness
14 Defendants argue the claims of โunnamed, future detaineesโ are unripe.  Fed. Opp. at 4.  The
15 argument misapprehends the ripeness doctrine, which prohibits courts from deciding theoretical or
16 abstract disagreements.  Meese, 871 F.2d at 883.  The dispute at issue -- concerning conditions of
17 confinement and detaineesโ due process rights -- is real and concrete rather than speculative and
18 hypothetical.  As discussed, Defendants acknowledge they have triple-celled detainees in the past and
19 dispute such conduct is unconstitutional.  The case is therefore ripe for review.
20 The inclusion of unnamed, future detainees who will be afefcted in the future by the challenged
21 policy is a common characteristic of class actions.  See, e.g. I.N.S. v. Natโl Ctr. for Immigrant Rights,
22 502 U.S. 183 (1991) (addressing merits of class action representing โall those persons who have been
23 or may in the future be denied the right to work pursuant to 8 CFR ยง 103.6); Does 1-5 v. Chandler,
24 83 F.3d 1150 (9th Cir. 1996) (addressing merits of class consisting of โ[a]ll persons who are, have
25 been, or will be identified as โdisabledโ under Chapter 346 ...โ); LaDuke v. Nelson, 762 F.2d 1318,
26 1321 (9th Cir. 1985) (affirming certification of class consisting of โ[a]ll persons who have resided or
27 will reside in particularly described farm housing ...โ).  To interpret ripeness as Defendants suggest
28 would โpreclude claims for injunctive relief on behalf of any โconstantly changingโ class, in which
- 6 -
05cv1013

1 new plaintiffs enter the cl ass by virtue of the passage of tim e.โ Santillan v. Ashcroft, 2004 WL
2 2297990, *7 (N.D. Cal. 2004) (citing Sze v. INS, 153 F.3d 1005, 1010 (9th Cir. 1998)).    
3 C. Certification
4 Defendants argue certification is unnecessary and, even if necessary, im proper because
5 Plaintiffs have not satisfied the commonality, typicality or adequacy of representation requirements
6 of Rule 23(a).  
7 1. Necessity
8 Defendants argue certification is unnecessary because the requested relief would apply to all
9 detainees.  CCA Opp. at 9.  CCA calims โ[n]o useful purpose would be served by permitting this case
10 to proceed as a class action,โ because the โdetermination of the constitutional question can be madeโ
11 without the need to certify the class.  Id. at 10 (citation omitted).
12 The Court disagrees.  Defendants acknowledge that the SDCF population fluctuates on a daily
13 basis and that Plaintiffs, named and unnamed, all risk being deported or transferred to other facilities
14 at any time.  In particular, two of the named plaintiffs are no longer before the Court as they have been
15 deported.  Given these facts, class certification is necessary because a named plaintiffโs claim could
16 be rendered moot (through deportation) before his claim is resolved.  See Pederson v. Louisiana State
17 Univ., 213 F.3d 858, 867 (5th Cir. 2000) (the substantial rsik of mootness creates a necessity for class
18 certification).
19 2. Rule 23(a)
20 (a) Numerosity
21 Rule 23(a)(1) requires that the class be โso num erous that joinder of all m embers is
22 impracticable.โ  Fed.R.Civ. P. 23(a)(1).  The Courft inds this element is met: the SAC proposes a class
23 of over 1000 detainees, including future detainees.   Joinder of all these individuals is clearly
24 impracticable, and Defendants do not suggest otherwise.  
25 (b) Commonality
26 Rule 23(a)(2) requires that โthere are questions of law or fact com mon to the class.โ
27 Fed.R.Civ.P. 23(a)(2).  โCommonality focuses on the relationship of common facts and legal issues
28 among class members.โ  Dukes, 474 F.3d at 1225.  This rule has been construed permissively.  โAll
- 7 -
05cv1013

1 questions of fact and law need not be common to satisfy the rule.  The existence of shared legal issues
2 with divergent factual predicates is sufficient,  as is a common core of salient facts coupled with
3 disparate legal remedies within the class.โ   Id.  โThe commonality test is qualitative rather than
4 quantitative โ one significant issue common to the class may be sufficient to warrant certification.โ
5 Id.  โPlaintiffs may demonstrate commonality by showing that class members have shared legal issues
6 by divergent facts or that they share a common core of facts but base their calims for relief on different
7 legal theories.โ  Id.
8 The SAC clearly presents at least โone significant issue commonโ to all class members.  It
9 alleges that all detainees at SDCF suffer from a condition of overcrowding stemming from, among
10 other things, Defendantsโ policy of triple-celling  detainees.  SAC, ยถ 54.  Pla intiffs contend these
11 practices โdeprive [them] of adequate shelter, reasonable safety, and basic human needs, and place
12 them at unreasonable, continuing and foreseeable riks of, inter alia, increased violence, illness, mental
13 suffering, and deteriorating health.โ  Id. at ยถ 111.  Factually, the allegations require this Court to
14 determine whether and to what extent practices such as triple-celling took place at SDCF.  In addition,
15 the allegations beg the question of how such practices impact the detainee population and whether
16 they violate the detaineesโ due process rights.  These factual questions are common to all detainees,
17 and satisfy Rule 23's commonality requirement.  
18 The federal defendants argue the commonality element is not met because โthere is no casual
19 link between the alleged harms and the defendantsโ actions,โ and the SAC โfails to show how any of
20 the alleged harms suffered by the named plaintiffs and the proposed class are specifically caused by
21 defendantsโ actions.โ Fed. Opp. at 7- 8.  Defendants further contend an examination of Plaintiffsโ
22 medical records โillustrates a myriad of injuries, ailm ents or illnesses am ong the plaintiffsโ are
23 โunrelated to any one source of conduct.โ   Id. at 8-9.  But the se contentions misapprehend class
24 certification jurisprudence.  
25 In evaluating a motion for class certification, โ[t]he court is bound to take the substantive
26 allegations of the complaint as true.โ Blackie, 524 F.2d at 901 n. 17; see also Thomas v. Baca, 231
27 F.R.D. 397, 399 (C.D. Cal. 2005) (citations omitted).  The question is not whether the plaintiffs have
28 stated a cause of action or will prevail on the merits, but rather whether the requirements of Rule 23
- 8 -
05cv1013

1 are met.  Id. (citations omitted).  Assuming as the Court must that the allegations in the SAC are true,
2 it is clear Plaintiffs have alleged common questions of law and fact. Whether the harms alleged are
3 caused by the practices in question goes to the merits of Plaintiffsโ claims.  
4 (c) Typicality
5 โAlthough the commonality and typicality requirements of Rule 23(a) tend to merge, each
6 factor serves discrete purpose.  Com monality examines the relationship of facts and legal issues
7 common to class members, while typicality focuses on the relationship of facts and issues between
8 the class and its representatives.โ  Dukes, 474 F.3d at 1231.  Rule 23(a)(3) requires that โthe claims
9 or defenses of t he representative parties are typi cal of the claim s or defenses of the class.โ
10 Fed.R.Civ.P. 23(a)(3).  Under the ruleโs permissive standard, โrepresentative claims are โtypicalโ if
11 they are reasonably coextensive with those of absent class members; they need not be substantially
12 identical.โ  Dukes, 474 F.3d at 1232.  โSome degree of individuality is to be expected in all cases, but
13 that specificity does not necessarily defeat typicality.โ  Id.
14 Plaintiffs argue โthe serious harm suffered by the putative named plaintiffs as a result of the
15 chronic and severe overcrowding at SDCF is typical of the type of harm experienced by other class
16 members.โ  Mt. for Cert. at 6.  The Court agrees. T  he SAC alleges all named plaintiffs have been or
17 are currently housed at SDCF.  All have experiencedso me if not all of thea llegedly wrongful policies.
18 Plaintiff Kiniti was triple-celled when he sought court permission to amend his complaint.  Owino,
19 who arrived at SDCF on November 8, 2005, alleges he was triple-celled for most of his detention at
20 SDCF.  SAC, at ยถ 16.  Delgado (who was recently transferred to another facility) alleges the same.
21 Id. at ยถ 18.  Like the named plaintiffs, the SAC alleges all putative class members were subjected to
22 similar treatment and thus, experienced similar harm.  Id. at ยถยถ 80-82.
23 Defendants nonetheless argue this element has not been met because โ[d]espite their broad
24 nature, plaintiffsโ allegations fail to identify even one specific injury that is inextricably tied to the
25 alleged overcrowding or triple-celling at SDCF.โ   Fed. Opp. at 12.  Defendants contend the SAC
26 โdetails isolated incidentsโ unrelated to the cl aims of misconduct, and โplaintiffs fail to link the
27 alleged injuries suffered by the named plaintiffs to any ICE policy or practice that was applied to the
28 proffered class as a whole.โ  Id. at 12-13.  As already discussed, these arguments concern the merits
- 9 -
05cv1013

1 of Plaintiffsโ claim: whether the alleged conduct caused the alleged injuries and, if so, whether the
2 conduct violates the detaineesโ constitutional rights.  Such issues are not appropriately addressed at
3 this stage of the proceeding.  Moreover, the argument does not address the typicality requirement.  
4 (d) Adequate Representation
5 Rule 23(a)(4) permits certification of a class action only if  โthe representative parties will
6 fairly and adequately protect the interests of the class.โ  Fed.R.Civ.P. 23(a)(4).  โThis factor requires:
7 (1) the proposed representative Plaintiffs do not havec onflicts of interest with the proposed class; and
8 (2) Plaintiffs are represented by qualified and competent counsel.โ  Dukes, 474 F.3d at 1233.  
9 Plaintiffs are represented by able counsel, and there is no conflict between the putative naemd
10 Plaintiffsโ interest and that of  the remaining class members.  The CCA Defendants contend this
11 element has not been met because โ[P]laintiffs have credibility problem, unique background issues
12 that are not representative of the typical immigrant detainees, and likely have individual concerns that
13 are not shared by the rest of the class.โ  CCA Opp. at 14.  The differences pointed out by CCA are not
14 relevant to determining whether the named Plaintiffs will adequately protect the interests o fthe class.
15 These differences or โindividual concernsโ do not giver ise to a conflict of interest between the named
16 Plaintiffs and the class. 
17 3. Rule 23(b)
18 Certification is appropriate pursuant to Rule2 3(b)(2) where โthe party opposing the class has
19 acted or refused to act on grounds generally applicable to the class, thereby making appropriate final
20 injunctive relief or corresponding declaratory relief withr espect to the class as a whole.โ  Mt. for Cert.
21 at 9 (citing Fed.R.Civ.P. 23(b)(2)).  The elements of subdivision 23(b)(2) are met.  
22 Plaintiffs allege Defendants engaged in conduct that is โgene rally applicable to the class.โ
23 According to Plaintiffs, Defendantsโs policy of triple-celling Plaintiffs, among other things, created
24 a chronic condition of overcrowding that deprived all detainees housed at SDCF personal security,
25 health care, and safety.  SAC at ยถ ยถ 41, 42.  Plaintiffs seek injunctive and declaratory relief to enjoin
26 these practices.  In light of these allegations and the relief sought, the requireemnts of 23(b)(2) clearly
27 are satisfied.  
28 D. 8 U.S.C. ยง 1252(f) and Differences In Plaintiffsโ Immigration Status
- 10 -
05cv1013

1 In their supplemental papers, Defendants argue (1) 8 U.S.C. ยง 1252( f) bars this case from
2 proceeding as an injunctive class  action, and (2) di fferences in the im migration status of class
3 members preclude certification.  Both arguments are unavailing for the reasons discussed below.
4 1. 8 U.S.C. ยง 1252(f)
5 Defendants contend โthe plain language of ยง 1252(f)(1) divests this Court of subject matter
6 jurisdiction over [P]laintiffsโ motion for certificationโ because that section limits the authority to
7 enjoin operation of certain detention statutes on a  class wide basis to the Supreme Court.  Section
8 1252(f)(1) provides: 
9 Regardless of the nature of the action  or claim or identity of the ... parties
bringing  the action, no court ( other  than  the Suprem e  Court) shall have
10 jurisdiction or authority to enjoin or restrain the operation of the provisions of
part IV of this sub-chapter [8 U.S.C. ยงยง 1221-1231], other than with respect to
11 the  application of such provisions to an individual alien against whom
proceedings under such part have been initiated.
12
13 In other words, according to D efendants, section 1252(f)(1) permits this Court to enjoin the
14 โoperationโ of certain detention statutes on an individual basis but not on a class wide basis.   
15 Neither  the plain l anguage  of section  1252(f)(1)  nor case law supports Defendantsโ
16 construction of the statute.  Rather, under section 1252(f)(1), class wide injunctions are prohibited
17 only if they suspend or restrain the operation of certain provisions of immigration law.  See Tefel v.
18 Reno,  972 F.Supp. 608, 618 (S.D. Fla. 1997)  vacated on other grounds, 180 F.3d 1286 (11th Cir.
19 1999) (finding ยง 1252(f)(1) did not bar injunctive relief for a class because plaintiffs sought not to
20 enjoin the statute but โconstitutional violationsโ and INS โpolicies and practices.โG);r imaldo v. Reno,
21 187 F.R.D. 643, 647-48 (D.Colo. 1999) (finding ยง 1252(f)(1) inapplicable where plaintiff sought to
22 convert complaint to a class action to โenjoin alleged constitutional violations by the INS in its
23 administrationโ of ยง 1226, not the operation of the stautte.)  In a decision that has been withdrawn on
24 other grounds, the Ninth Circuit held section 1252(f)(1) is inapplicable where the injunctive relief
25 sought pertains not to โthe operation of ยง 1231(b) but violations of the statute and to โensure that the
26 provision is properly implemented.โโ  Ali v. Ashcroft, 346 F.3d 873 886 (9th Cir. 2003) (emphasis in
27 original). 
28 Here, Plaintiffs do not seek to suspend or restrain the operation of any immigration statutes.
- 11 -
05cv1013

1 Nor do they challenge the Governmentโs interpretation of any such statute.  Rather, Plaintiffs claim
2 the manner in which the Government carries out its authority under the relevant statutes violates their
3 substantive due process rights.  Thus, Plaintiffs do not seek to suspend the Governmentโs authority
4 to detain and remove aliens; they simply assert that the Governm ent is obligated to carry out its
5 statutory powers in a constitutional manner. 
6 Defendants, however, contend this case โclearly fallsโ under the scope of section 1252(f)(1)
7 because class wide injunction, if granted, would  โcurtail[] [the Agencyโs] managerial discretionโ
8 relating to detention and removal of aliens.  Fed. Supp. Brief at 5.  In particular, Defendants argue the
9 injunction would impact the Agencyโs decisions regarding where to house detainees and the manner
10 in which they are detained.  Defendantsโ inte rpretation of section 1252(f)(1) is overly broad, not
11 supported by case law and the text of the statute, and effectively would preclude a court from issuing
12 injunctive  relief  in any m atter  that tangentially  related  to detention of a liens.   Accordingly,
13 Defendantsโ interpretation of the statute is rej ected.  This case f alls outside the jurisdictional
14 restrictions of section 1252(f)(1).   
15 2. Differences In Detaineesโ Immigration Status
16 Defendants argue the difference in immigration status of class members bars certification.  The
17 proposed class โ present and future detainees housed at SDCF โ include two categories of detainees:
18 detainees who (1) already have entered the United States, and (2) are detained either before entry in
19 the United States or inside the United States but within 100 air miles of the border.  The latter group
20 of aliens is referred to as โexpedited removalsโ or โexcludable aliens,โ as they are deemed not to have
21 effected entry into the country even htough they are physically detained here.S  ee Barrera-Echavarria
22 v. Rison, 44 F.3d 1441, 1450 (9th Cir 1995) (โentry fictionโ provides that โ[a]lthough aliens seeking
23 admission into the United States may physically be allowed within its borders pending a determination
24 of admissibility, such aliens are legally considered to be detained at the border and hence as never
25 having effected entry into this countryโ)( internal quotations and citations omitted), overruled on other
26 grounds, Xi v. I.N.S., 298 F.3d 832 (9th Cir. 2002).  
27 The named Plaintiffs are all non-excludable aliens, whereas the proposed class contains both
28 excludable and non-excludable aliens.  Defendants argue the two groups have different substantive
- 12 -
05cv1013

1 constitutional rights, and the Court will have to appyl different legal standards in determining whether
2 the detention practices in question  violate  each groupโs rights.  CCA Supp. Brief at 3.  This
3 difference, according to Defendants, prevents Pl aintiffs from meeting Rule 23's r equirements of
4 adequacy of representation, typicality, and commonality. 
5 As an initial matter, the cases Defendants rely on to support their contention have lim ited
6 application โ holding only that excludable aliens have le ss procedural rights than other aliens.
7 Defendants rely principally on  Lynch v. Cannatella, 810 F.2d 1363 (5th Cir. 1987) .  There, the
8 plaintiffs were sixteen Jamaican nationals who attempted to enter the United States illegally by
9 stowing away aboard a grain barge bound for ports  on the Mississippi River.  Plaintiffs were
10 discovered, and, subsequently, they sued federal and state officials claiming physical abuse prior to
11 being deported.  The language in Lynch that Defendants seize upon is the following: โ[e]xcludable
12 aliens . . . are situated differently even from illegal aliens who have landed in this country.โ  Id. at
13 1373.  The court in Lynch, however, strongly suggested that the distinction between excludable and
14 non-excludable aliens relates only to the process of deportation: โThe โentry fictionโ that excludable
15 aliens are to be treated as if detained at the bodrer despite their physical presence in the United States
16 determines the aliensโ rights with regard to immigration and deportation proceedings.  It does not limit
17 the right of excludable aliens detained within United States territory to humane treatment.โ  Id.  
18 Lynch makes clear that the basis of the โentry fi ctionโ is the โoverriding concern that the
19 United States, as a sovereign, maintain its right to self-determination.โ  Lynch, 810 F.2d at 1373.  In
20 other words, the conclusion that excludable aliensh ave less procedural rights promotes the sovereign
21 interest of the United States in admitting or rejecting outsiders as it sees f it.  The interest in self-
22 determination, however, โplays virtually no roleโ in determining whether the Constitution affords
23 excludable aliens substantive due process rights.  See Id. at 1374.  The Lynch court observed it could
24 not โconceive of any national interestsโ that would justify depriving the plaintiffs of the right to be
25 treated humanely merely because they are excludable aliens.   Id.  โ[W]hatever due process rights
26 excludable aliens may be denied by virtue of th eir status, they are entitled under the due process
27 clauses of the fifth and fourteenth amendments to be free of gross physical abuse at the hands of state
28 or federal officials.โ Id. 
- 13 -
05cv1013

1 Similarly, in Wong v. United States, 373 F.3d 952 (2003), the Nint h Circuit concluded the
2 entry fiction is โbest seen [] as a fairly narrow doctrine that primarily determines procedures that the
3 executive branch must follow before turning an immigrant away.โ Id. at 973.  Reasoning โthe entry
4 fiction does not preclude substantive constitutional protection,โ  id. at 971, the court observed the
5 doctrine appears โdeterminative of the procedural rightso f aliens with respect to their applications ofr
6 admission,โ and has not been used to โdeny all constitutional rights to non-admitted aliens.โ  Id. at
7 973.  
8 Although case law suggests the entry fiction is  determinative only of procedural rights,
9 Defendants are correct that no court has explicitly held that excludable aliens enjoy the same bundle
10 of substantive rights as non-excludable aliens.  But this Court need not answer that question.
11 Defendants suggest that while both groups of aliens may be entitled to humane treatment, one may
12 be entitled to better treatment than the other.  In other words, Def endants essentially contend the
13 Government, consistent with Fifth Amendment due process rights, conceivably may be permitted to
14 triple-cell one group but not the other group.  Thisi s because excludable aliens are only entitled to be
15 free from โgross physical abuseโ that results in โserious physical harm,โ  CCA Supp. Brief at 4, while
16 non-excludable aliens are entitled โto the โminimum civilized measure of lifeโs necessity.โโ  Id.  But
17 the cases Defendants rely on neither support the claim that the former standard applies to excludable
18 aliens while the latter applies to non-excludable aliens, nor that one standard is more stringent than
19 the other.  
20 Moreover, even assuming the right to humane treatment is governed by different standards,
21 Defendants have not explained in what way any such differences should bar class certifi cation.
22 Defendants suggest the named Plaintiffs, all non-excludable aliens, may not adequately represent those
23 who are excludable.  The Court disagrees.  Differences in the legal standards to be applied, if any, do
24 not suggest any conflict of interes tbetween the named Plaintiffs and unnamed class members.  Rather,
25 if the named Plaintiffs are entitled to an injunction, the unnam ed excludable plaintiffs also will
26 benefit.1  Theoretically, under Defendantsโ construct, it i sonly problematic if the named Plaintiffs are
27 excludable aliens, and therefore they would not be ab le to adequately represent the unnamed non-
28
1  Defendants after all have argued that c ertification is unnecessary because the requested
relief, if granted, would apply to all detainees.  See CCA Opp. at 9.  
- 14 -
05cv1013

1 excludable class members, who may be entitled to more rights or better treatment.  The purported
2 differences between excludable and non-excludable aliens do not negate any of the requirements of
3 Rule 23.  
4 IV. 
5 CONCLUSION
6 For these reasons, Plaintiffsโ motion for class certification is GRANTED.  
7 IT IS SO ORDERED.
8 DATED: August 17, 2007, 
9
10 HON. DANA M. SABRAW
United States District Judge

documents.text:
Case 3:05-cv-01013-DMS-PCL     Document 36     Filed 01/24/2007     Page 1 of 11(cid:10)
1 Gouri Bhat (pro hac vice pending)
Tom-Tsvi M. Jawetz (pro hac vice pending)
2 David C. Fathi* (pro hac vice pending)
American Civil Liberties Union Foundation
3      National Prison Project
915 15th Street NW, 7th Floor
4 Washington, DC  20005
Tel: (202) 548-6611
5 *Not admitted in DC; practice limited to federal courts
6 Judy Rabinovitz (pro hac vice pending)
American Civil Liberties Union Foundation
7      Immigrantsโ Rights Project
125 Broad Street, 18th Floor
8 New York, NY  10004
Tel: (212) 549-2618 
9
Anthony M. Stiegler (SBN 126414)
10 Mary Kathryn Kelley (SBN 170259)
Cooley Godward Kronish LLP
11 4401 Eastgate Mall
San Diego, CA  92121-1909
12 Tel: (858) 550-6035
13 Counsel for Plaintiff
[Additional Counsel Appear on Signature Page]
14
15 UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
FOR THE SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA
16
ISAAC KIGONDU KINITI, ) Case No. 3:05-cv-01013-DMS-PCL
17 )
Plaintiff, ) MEMORANDUM OF POINTS AND
18 ) AUTHORITIES IN SUPPORT OF
v. ) MOTION FOR CLASS CERTIFICATION
19   ) UNDER THE [PROPOSED] SECOND
BARBARA WAGNER, et al., ) AMENDED COMPLAINT
20 )
Defendants. )
21 )
22 Introduction
23 This action began in May 2005 with the filing of a pro se Complaint by plaintiff Isaac
24 Kigondu Kiniti.  In his original Complaint, as in his First Amended Complaint, Mr. Kiniti alleges
25 violations of his constitutional rights stemming from, inter alia, the severe and chronic
26 overcrowding of immigration detainees at San Diego Correctional Facility (SDCF).  On January
27 24, 2007, plaintiff Kiniti, by and through his attorneys, filed under separate cover a Motion for
28 Leave to Amend the First Amended Complaint and Add Parties.  Plaintiffโs Proposed Second
1

Case 3:05-cv-01013-DMS-PCL     Document 36     Filed 01/24/2007     Page 2 of 11(cid:10)
1 Amended Complaint, attached to the aforementioned motion for leave to amend, contains class
2 action allegations on behalf of the class of โall immigration detainees in ICE custody who are
3 now or in the future will be confined at San Diego Correctional Facilityโ (hereinafter the โSDCF
4 Classโ), and seeks only injunctive and declaratory relief.
5 In the Proposed Second Amended Complaint, the putative class alleges that more than
6 two-thirds of the detainees at SDCF are currently affected by the practice of triple-celling (i.e.,
7 housing three detainees in a small cell designed for two), that still more detainees are housed in
8 makeshift beds in the common dayroom space, and that all detainees are at risk of future harm
9 from this chronic and severe overcrowding.  Putative representative plaintiffs further allege that
10 the long-standing and pervasive overcrowding at SDCF:
11 is the root cause of numerous unsafe and intolerable conditions that
afflict detainees at the facility, including: increased violence, tension,
12 discomfort,  stress,  mental  suffering,  psychiatric  problems,  and
exposure to respiratory and other infections; diminished access to
13 medical, mental health and dental services; diminished access to
exercise  and  dayroom  space  and  other  facility  services;  poor
14 sanitation  and  decreased  ability  to  maintain  personal  hygiene;
overburdened and unsanitary shower and toilet facilities, resulting in
15 more frequent plumbing malfunctions and exposure to urine and
feces; and the loss of personal dignity due to all of the above.
16
Proposed Second Amended Complaint, ยถ 3.
17
In connection with the class action allegations contained in the Proposed Second
18
Amended Complaint, which is to be filed with the Court and served on all defendants should the
19
Court grant plaintiffโs motion for leave to amend, plaintiff hereby moves for certification of the
20
SDCF Class and an order appointing the undersigned counsel to represent the certified class,
21
pursuant to Rule 23(g) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.
22
For the reasons set forth below, plaintiffโs Motion for Class Certification Under the
23
[Proposed] Second Amended Complaint should be granted, and an order should be issued
24
appointing the undersigned as class counsel.
25
I. This Case is Properly Maintained as a Class Action.
26
A.  Background Principles Applicable to Class Certification
27
In order for a class to be certified, the following requirements must be satisfied: 
28
(1)  the  class  is  so  numerous  that  joinder  of  all  members  is
2 05cv01013

Case 3:05-cv-01013-DMS-PCL     Document 36     Filed 01/24/2007     Page 3 of 11(cid:10)
1 impracticable, (2) there are questions of law or fact common to the
class, (3) the claims or defenses of the representative parties are
2 typical  of  the  claims  or  defenses  of  the  class,  and  (4)  the
representative parties will fairly and adequately protect the interests
3 of the class.
4 Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a).  In addition, the class must meet the requirements of one of the three
5 subsections set forth in Rule 23(b).  Here, plaintiff Kiniti and putative named plaintiffs Jose
6 Morales-Vargas, Sylvester Owino, Hernan Ismael Delgado and Any Castro seek certification
7 pursuant to Rule 23(b)(2).
8 Initial determination of class certification is solely a procedural issue that must not be
9 based on the merits of the case; plaintiffโs burden is limited to demonstrating that the proposed
10 class satisfies the requirements of Rule 23.  Eisen v. Carlisle & Jacquelin, 417 U.S. 156, 178
11 (1974).  In ruling on the motion for class certification, the Court must take the substantive
12 allegations of the Proposed Second Amended Complaint as true.  Blackie v. Barrack, 524 F.2d
13 891, 901 n.17 (9th Cir. 1975).
14 B.  The Rule 23(a) Prerequisites to Class Certification Have Been Satisfied.
15 1.  Numerosity and Impracticality of Joinder
16 The first prerequisite of Rule 23(a) is that โthe class [be] so numerous that joinder of all
17 members is impracticable.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(1).  While there is no ironclad rule as to when
18 the size of the proposed class renders joinder impracticable, sheer numerosity is generally
19 sufficient.  Jordan v. County of Los Angeles, 669 F.2d 1311, 1319 (9th Cir. 1982), vacated on
20 other grounds, 459 U.S. 810 (1982), on remand, 713 F.2d 504 (9th Cir. 1983); 5 Mooreโs
21 Federal Practice, ยง23.22[3][a] (Matthew Bender, 3d ed.) (hereinafter โMooreโs Federal
22 Practiceโ) (noting that classes comprising more than 40 individuals are generally found to satisfy
23 the impracticality of joinder requirement).  Where, as in this case, the proposed class exceeds
24 1000 immigration detainees, joinder is clearly impracticable.
25 Joinder of all class members is further complicated by the nature of immigration
26 detention, which is often quite fluid.  The size and make-up of the proposed classโwhich
27 includes immigration detainees who are not now, but will in the future be, detained at
28 SDCFโchange daily, as additional detainees are brought to SDCF to be held in the custody of
3 05cv01013

Case 3:05-cv-01013-DMS-PCL     Document 36     Filed 01/24/2007     Page 4 of 11(cid:10)
1 the Department of Homeland Security, Immigration and Customs Enforcement, while other class
2 members are released from detention, removed from the country, or transferred to other detention
3 facilities.  The rotating membership of the proposed class is an additional basis for finding
4 joinder impracticable.  See Andre H. v. Ambach, 104 F.R.D. 606, 611 (S.D.N.Y. 1985) (โThe fact
5 that the [detention center] population . . . is constantly revolving establishes sufficient numerosity
6 to make joinder of the class members impracticable.โ).  The inclusion in the class of future
7 detainees, whose identities cannot possibly be ascertained at this time, provides still further basis
8 for concluding that joinder is impracticable.  See, e.g., Jones v. Diamond, 519 F.2d 1090, 1100
9 (5th Cir. 1975); Skinner v. Uphoff, 209 F.R.D. 484, 488 (D. Wyo. 2002) (finding certification
10 appropriate for class of current and future prisoners seeking injunctive relief; โ[a]s members in
11 futuro, they are necessarily unidentifiable, and therefore joinder is clearly impracticableโ);
12 Mooreโs Federal Practice, ยง23.22[7].
13 Finally, courts typically find joinder to be impracticable if it is reasonable to conclude that
14 the class members would be unable to file individual actions to vindicate their rights.  See, e.g.,
15 Leyva v. Buley, 125 F.R.D. 512, 515 (E.D. Wash. 1989) (certifying class of migrant workers and
16 citing class membersโ lack of sophistication, limited knowledge of the legal system, limited or
17 non-existent English skills, and fear of retaliation).  Such is the case with the purported class
18 members, who have even less access to the legal system than pre-trial criminal detainees;
19 immigration detainees appearing in Immigration Court and before the Board of Immigration
20 Appeals have only a statutory โprivilege of being represented (at no expense to the
21 Government).โ  8 U.S.C. ยง 1362.
22 2.  Commonality
23 The second prerequisite of Rule 23(a) is that there be a single question of law or fact
24 common to members of the class.  Blackie v. Barrack, 524 F.2d 891, 904 (9th Cir. 1975) (โall
25 that is required is a single issue of law or factโ); see also Marisol A. v. Giuliani, 126 F.3d 372,
26 376 (2d Cir. 1997).  The Proposed Second Amended Complaint in this action identifies multiple
27 questions of both law and fact common to the entire class.
28 These common questions include, but are not limited to: whether defendants have failed
4 05cv01013

Case 3:05-cv-01013-DMS-PCL     Document 36     Filed 01/24/2007     Page 5 of 11(cid:10)
1 to provide adequate shelter, reasonable safety, and basic human needs to plaintiffs as a result of
2 overcrowding at SDCF; whether plaintiffsโ conditions of confinement subject them to
3 unreasonable risk of violence, injury, illness and mental suffering; whether plaintiffsโ conditions
4 of confinement are effectively punitive; whether defendantsโ conduct violates the Fifth
5 Amendment; and whether defendantsโ conduct shows a pattern of officially sanctioned behavior
6 that violates plaintiffsโ rights and establishes a credible threat of future injury.
7 The commonality prerequisite is therefore satisfied.1
8 3.  Typicality
9 The third prerequisite of Rule 23(a) is that the putative named plaintiffsโ claims be typical
10 of those of the class.  The purpose of this requirement is to assure that the interests of the named
11 plaintiffs align with the interests of the class.  Weinberger v. Thornton, 114 F.R.D. 599, 603
12 (S.D. Cal. 1986).  This prerequisite is viewed under the ruleโs โpermissive standards,โ such that
13 โrepresentative claims are โtypicalโ if they are reasonably co-extensive with those of absent class
14 members; they need not be substantially identical.โ  Hanlon v. Chrysler Corp., 150 F.3d 1011,
15 1019 (9th Cir. 1998).  See also Penn v. San Juan Hospital, Inc., 528 F.2d 1181, 1189 (10th Cir.
16 1975) (โthe typicality requirement is ordinarily not argued.โ).
17 The typicality requirement is satisfied โ[i]f the class representativeโs claims arise from the
18 same events, practice, or conduct, and are based on the same legal theory as those of other class
19 members.โ  Mooreโs Federal Practice, ยง23.24[2].  The fundamental inquiry for typicality is
20 whether all members of the class would benefit in some way from a judgment favorable to the
21
22
1 Of course, factual differences may exist among class members with respect to the
precise way in which each individual is affected by the institutional practice or
23
condition.  Such differences do not defeat commonality.  See, e.g., Marisol A, 126 F.3d
24 at 377 (โthe unique circumstances of each [plaintiff] do not compromise the common
question of whether . . . defendants have injured all class members by failing to meet
25
their federal and state law obligationsโ); Milonas v. Williams, 691 F.2d 931, 938 (10th
Cir. 1982) (โ[f]actual differences in the claims of class members should not result in a
26
denial of class certification where common questions of law existโ); see also Bradley v.
27 Harrelson, 151 F.R.D. 422, 426 (M.D. Ala. 1993) (concluding that factual differences
between class members as to the nature and severity of their mental illness do not
28
preclude finding of commonality in a class action challenging the delivery of mental
health services to Alabama prisoners).
5 05cv01013

Case 3:05-cv-01013-DMS-PCL     Document 36     Filed 01/24/2007     Page 6 of 11(cid:10)
1 plaintiffs.  See Ellis v. Naval Air Rework Facility, 404 F. Supp. 391, 396 (N.D. Cal. 1975).  
2 The putative named plaintiffs are immigration detainees at SDCF who have personally
3 experienced the consequences of the defendantsโ policies, practices, acts and omissions
4 pertaining to the chronic and severe overcrowding of SDCF.  With the exception of plaintiff
5 Isaac Kigondu Kiniti, each of the other putative named plaintiffs is currently triple-celled. 
6 Plaintiff Jose Morales-Vargas has been housed at SDCF since June 16, 2006, and has been
7 continuously triple-celled with the exception of a brief 11-day period when he was housed in
8 segregation.  Proposed Second Amended Complaint, ยถ 14.  Plaintiff Sylvester Owino arrived at
9 SDCF on November 8, 2005.  Id. at ยถ 15.  He has been triple-celled for most of his detention at
10 SDCF and without interruption since June 11, 2006.  Id. at ยถ 16.  Plaintiff Hernan Ismael
11 Delgado is also currently triple-celled.  Id. at ยถ 18.  Delgado has been in ICE detention since
12 February 2003, and has been housed at SDCF since October 8, 2004.  Id.  Delgado has been
13 triple-celled for the majority of his time at SDCF, and was forced to sleep on the floor in a plastic
14 โboatโ containing a thin sleeping mat for the first six months of his detention at SDCF.  Id. 
15 Plaintiff Any Castro has been detained at SDCF since September 2006, and has been triple-celled
16 for the entirety of her stay in detention.  Id. at ยถ 20.  Like plaintiff Delgado, plaintiff Castro was
17 forced to sleep on the floor of her cell in a โboatโ for the first two months of her time at SDCF. 
18 Id.  Although plaintiff Kiniti is not now triple-celled, Kiniti has been triple-celled at various
19 points during his stay in SDCF and remains at constant risk of once again being triple-celled, or
20 suffering the consequences of his refusal to be triple-celled.  Id. at ยถ 12.  In early 2005, Kiniti
21 complained to auditors from the Department of Homeland Security Office of Inspector General
22 (OIG) about the problem of overcrowding and triple-celling at SDCF, and personally met with a
23 senior auditor for the OIG during her visit to the facility.  Id.  Kiniti subsequently filed the instant
24 lawsuit arguing, inter alia, that triple-celling and overcrowding at SDCF are unconstitutional.
25 The serious harm suffered by the putative named plaintiffs as a result of the chronic and
26 severe overcrowding at SDCF is typical of the type of harm experienced by other class members. 
27 This harm includes not only the concrete harm of being triple-celledโa harm that is itself
28 experienced by two-thirds of the immigration detainees now held at SDCFโbut also all of the
6 05cv01013

Case 3:05-cv-01013-DMS-PCL     Document 36     Filed 01/24/2007     Page 7 of 11(cid:10)
1 other dangers and indignities that accompany this overcrowding.  Pervasive overcrowding at
2 SDCF increases the tension between detainees at the facility, who are forced to spend significant
3 periods of time confined in cells that are designed to house two, not three, people.  Plaintiff
4 Morales-Vargas has had to defend himself in at least five incidents of detainee-on-detainee
5 violence that went unnoticed or ignored by security staff, and plaintiff Owino has witnessed
6 numerous fights among detainees that have transpired without the intervention of security staff. 
7 Id. at ยถ 72.  When plaintiff Castro was first brought to SDCF, she spent two months sleeping on
8 the floor of her cell in a โboat.โ  Id. at ยถ 20.
9 All detainees are also at heightened risk of illness as a result of the severe and chronic
10 overcrowding at SDCF.  Id. at ยถยถ 80-82.  Detainees living in severely overcrowded conditions are
11 at greater risk for both methicillin resistant staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and multidrug
12 resistant tuberculosis (MDRTB).  MRSA is a highly contagious bacteria known to spread rapidly
13 in institutional settings where poor sanitation and close confinement create a greater likelihood of
14 transmission.  MDRTB is a potentially fatal air-borne disease that can spread in overcrowded
15 conditions with poor air circulation.
16 Plaintiffโs counsel have interviewed and corresponded with numerous putative class
17 members who are suffering the same constitutional injury as the putative named plaintiffs
18 because of the overcrowding of SDCF.  Counsel have also interviewed and corresponded with
19 individuals who are not now detained at SDCF, but were detained at that facility within the past
20 several months, who similarly experienced constitutional deprivations as a result of the
21 overcrowding.  Some of the allegations contained in the Proposed Second Amended Complaint
22 pertain to the experiences of individuals who, though they are not putative representative
23 plaintiffs, are members of the putative SDCF Class.  See, e.g., id. at  ยถยถ 77, 83, 84.  The claims of
24 the putative named plaintiffs are typical of those of the class; they are โpart of the class and
25 possess the same interest and suffer the same injury as the class members.โ  East Texas Motor
26 Freight System, Inc. v. Rodriguez, 431 U.S. 395, 403 (1977) (internal quotation marks omitted).
27
28
7 05cv01013

Case 3:05-cv-01013-DMS-PCL     Document 36     Filed 01/24/2007     Page 8 of 11(cid:10)
1 4.  Adequacy of Representation
2 The fourth prerequisite of Rule 23(a) is that โthe representative parties will fairly and
3 adequately protect the interests of the class.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(4).  Adequacy of
4 representation is a two-part test: (i) counsel for the representative parties are qualified and able to
5 prosecute the action vigorously; and (ii) there is no conflict or antagonism between the named
6 plaintiffsโ interests and the remainder of the class.  Lerwill v. Inflight Motion Pictures, Inc., 582
7 F.2d 507, 522 (9th Cir. 1978).
8 Plaintiff class members are represented by the National Prison Project of the American
9 Civil Liberties Union Foundation (NPP), the Immigrantsโ Rights Project of the American Civil
10 Liberties Union Foundation (IRP), the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation of San Diego
11 & Imperial Counties (ACLU of San Diego), and the law firm of Cooley Godward Kronish LLP
12 (CGK).  NPP has extensive experience litigating class actions regarding conditions inside prisons
13 and jails, and IRP has unique expertise pertaining to the detention of individuals by ICE.  The
14 ACLU of San Diego, through its legal director, and CGK each has significant experience in civil
15 rights and immigrantsโ rights litigation.  Counsel are therefore experienced in class action, civil
16 rights, immigrantsโ rights, and conditions of confinement litigation.
17 There is also no conflict between the putative named plaintiffsโ interests and the
18 remainder of the class.  The putative named plaintiffs have no interests separate from those of a
19 putative SDCF Class, and seek no relief other than the classwide injunctive and declaratory relief
20 sought on behalf of the class.2
21
22
23
2 In addition to seeking injunctive relief in his Complaint and First Amended Complaint,
24 plaintiff Kiniti also sought damages for the injury he personally suffered as a result of
Defendantsโ unconstitutional actions.  In the Proposed Second Amended Complaint, Mr.
25
Kiniti has withdrawn his request for damages and instead is pursuing only injunctive and
declaratory relief as a representative of the putative class.  However, even if Mr. Kiniti
26
were to continue to seek damages in this action, that would not create a conflict of
27 interest preventing class certification.  See, e.g., Probe v. State Teachersโ Retirement
System, 780 F.2d 776, 780-81 (9th Cir. 1986).  Here, as in Probe, any request for money
28
damages by Mr. Kiniti would be merely incidental to the primary claims common to all
named plaintiffs and the class as a whole regarding injunctive relief.
8 05cv01013

Case 3:05-cv-01013-DMS-PCL     Document 36     Filed 01/24/2007     Page 9 of 11(cid:10)
1 C.  Class Certification is Appropriate Pursuant to Rule 23(b)(2).
2 The final requirement for class certification is satisfaction of at least one of the
3 subsections of Rule 23(b).  Certification is appropriate pursuant to Rule 23(b)(2) where:
4 the party opposing the class has acted or refused to act on grounds
generally applicable to the class, thereby making appropriate final
5 injunctive relief or corresponding declaratory relief with respect to
the class as a whole.
6
Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(2).  Courts have repeatedly held that civil rights class actions are the
7
paradigmatic 23(b)(2) suits, โfor they seek classwide structural relief that would clearly redound
8
equally to the benefit of each class member.โ  Marcera v. Chinlund, 595 F.2d 1231, 1240 (2d
9
Cir. 1979), vacated on other grounds sub nom., Lombard v. Marcera, 442 U.S. 915 (1979); see
10
also Johnson v. General Motors Corp., 598 F.2d 432, 435 (5th Cir. 1979); Elliott v. Weinberger,
11
564 F.2d 1219, 1229 (9th Cir. 1977) (action to enjoin allegedly unconstitutional government
12
conduct is โthe classic type of action envisioned by the drafters of Rule 23 to be brought under
13
subdivision (b)(2)โ), affโd in pertinent part sub nom., Califano v. Yamasaki, 442 U.S. 682, 701
14
(1979)).  As stated in the leading treatise on class actions:
15
Rule 23(b)(2) was drafted specifically to facilitate relief in civil rights
16 suits.  Most class actions in the constitutional and civil rights areas
seek primarily declaratory and injunctive relief on behalf of the class
17 and therefore readily satisfy Rule 23(b)(2) class action criteria.
18 A. Conte & H. Newberg, Newberg on Class Actions ยง 25.20 (4th ed. 2002).  
19 Injunctive challenges to prison conditions routinely proceed as class actions, and are
20 typically maintained under subdivision (b)(2).  See, e.g., JonesโEl v. Berge, 374 F.3d 541 (7th
21 Cir. 2004); Hoptowit v. Ray, 682 F.2d 1237, 1245 (9th Cir. 1982) (class certified under Rule
22 23(b)(2)); Diamond, 519 F.2d at 1097, 1099-1100 (encouraging the liberal application of Rule
23 23, and in particular subdivision (b)(2), in civil rights actions, and observing that โ[r]ealistically,
24 class actions are the only practicable judicial mechanism for the cleansing reformation and
25 purification of these penal institutions.โ).
26 In this case, the defendantsโ unconstitutional policies, practices, acts and omissions
27 pertaining to overcrowding are imposed uniformly on all class members, and declaratory and
28 injunctive relief will redound to the benefit of the class as a whole.  Accordingly, Rule 23(b)(2) is
9 05cv01013

Case 3:05-cv-01013-DMS-PCL     Document 36     Filed 01/24/2007     Page 10 of 11(cid:10)
1 satisfied.
2 Conclusion
3 For the reasons set forth above, Plaintiffโs Motion for Class Certification Under the
4 [Proposed] Second Amended Complaint should be granted, and plaintiffโs counsel should be
5 appointed to represent the certified class, pursuant to Rule 23(g) of the Federal Rules of Civil
6 Procedure.
7
8 Dated: January 24, 2007 Respectfully submitted,
9
By: s/ David Blair-Loy
