1  This motion to dismiss is filed on behalf of the Federal Defendants.  The United States
28 does not represent defendants Corrections Corporation of America (CCA), Joe Easterling, or
Charles Howard in this matter. 
Memorandum of Points and Authorities in Support of Defendantsโ Motion to Dismiss
3:05-cv-1013-DMS-PCL

Case 3:05-cv-01013-DMS-PCL     Document 75     Filed 05/04/2007     Page 2 of 10
1 INTRODUCTION AND BACKGROUND
2 This case began on May 9, 2005,when plaintiff IsaacKigonduKiniti (โKinitiโ) filed a pro se
3 Complaint, alleging, amongother things, constitutional violations stemming from the overcrowding
4 of U.S. Immigration andCustomsEnforcement(ICE)detaineeshoused at the San Diego Correctional
5 Facility (SDCF), acontractdetentionfacilityin OtayMesa,California,operatedby CCA.  The initial
6 Complaint named CCA, the warden of the facility, and several SDCF officers as defendants.  The
7 Court reviewed the Complaint on its own initiative, dismissed a number of claims without prejudice,
8 and dismissed several named defendants.  The Court also granted Kiniti leave to file an amended
9 complaint and instructed him to identifythosedefendantsto whomhe had complained regarding the
10 conditions of his confinement.  On June 29, 2006, Kiniti, still pro se, filed his First Amended
11 Complaint, and the original defendants filed an Answer on October 30, 2006.
12       On January 24, 2007, Kiniti, now represented by the ACLU, filed a motion for leave to file his
13 Second Amended Complaint, wherein he requested certification of a class in addition to both
14 declaratory and injunctive relief on behalf of the ICE immigration detainees housed at SDCF.  The
15 new complaint added plaintiffs and replaced almost all of the defendants, substituting four ICE
16 officials and the current warden and assistant warden of SDCF as the related SDCF officers, and
17 replacingthe former warden as a named defendant.  The Second Amended Complaint also allegesfor
18 the first time that defendants engaged in the practice of overcrowding and triple-celling immigration
19 detainees at SDCF. Accordingto plaintiffs, this practice results in theviolation of the  immigration
20 detaineesโ constitutional rights.  On February 27, 2007, the Court granted plaintiffsโ motion for leave
21 to file the Second AmendedComplaint, and theSecondAmendedComplaint was deemed filed on that
22 date.2
23 The Court initially addressed the issue of mootness in its February 27, 2007 order, when the
24 Court addressed defendantsโ argument that amending the First Amended Complaint was futile
25 because, among other things, plaintiffs were no longer subject to triple-celling conditions and
26
27
2  While Kinitiโs litigation has been ongoing for some time, the Federal Defendants were
28
not a party to this lawsuit until February 27, 2007, when the Second Amended Complaint was
deemed filed.
Memorandum of Points and Authorities in Support of Defendantsโ Motion to Dismiss
3:05-cv-1013-DMS-PCL 2

Case 3:05-cv-01013-DMS-PCL     Document 75     Filed 05/04/2007     Page 3 of 10
1 therefore lacked standing to bring suit.  See Order Granting Plaintiffโs Motion to Amend First
2 Amended Complaint and Add Parties (โOrderโ) at 4.  The Court granted leave to file the Second
3 Amended Complaint, noting that โDefendantsโ argument that Plaintiffsโ claims are moot assumes the
4 injuries alleged stem solely from โtriple-celling,โ and the Court found that โ[t]his is not the case.โ
5 Id. Asthe Courtexplained, plaintiffsโ proposed Second Amended Complaint alleges a โchronic and
6 severe overcrowdingโthatincludes notonlytriple-celling, but allegationsthat immigration detainees
7 were forced to sleep on makeshift beds in the common dayroom space; that detainees experienced
8 overcrowding in holding cells; and that overflow detainees and detainees who refuse to be triple-celled
9 are subject to oppressive confinement conditions intheadministrativesegregation unit.  Id.  The Court
10 also noted that while defendants claimed that 104 detainees were permanently discharged or
11 transferred from SDCF, defendants did not contend that the individual pods did not exceed their
12 capacity.  Id. at 5.
13 Furthermore, the Court stated, defendants did notmeet their โheavyburden of persuadingโ the
14 Court that triple-celling cannot reasonably be expected to start up again.  Id.  Citing the case of
15 Friends of the Earth, Inc. v. Laidlaw Envtl. Serv., Inc., 528 U.S. 167, 189 (2000), the Court reasoned
16 that while a defendantโs voluntary cessation of a challenged practice does not deprive a federal court
17 of its power to determine the legality of the practice, โ[a] case might become moot if subsequent
18 events made it absolutelyclear that the allegedlywrongfulbehaviorcould notbe reasonably expected
19 to occur.โ  Applying this standard, the Court held that  defendantsโ assertion that no detainees are
20 currently triple-celled failed to establish that it was absolutely clear that the triple-celling and other
21 conditions related to overcrowding could not be reasonably expected to recur.  Id.
22   In contrast, this present motion to dismiss based on mootness is distinguishable from this
23 prior argument opposing the Motion for Leave to File the Second Amended Complaint.  First,
24 defendants address not only the triple-celling allegations, but the other allegations referenced in the
25 Courtโs February 27, 2007 Order that relate to issuesof overcrowding.  Second, defendants meet the
26 Friendsof the Earth standard in showingthatplaintiffsโ case is moot bymaking it โabsolutely clearโ
27 that the challenged conduct alleged in the Second Amended Complaint could not reasonably be
28 expected to recur.
Memorandum of Points and Authorities in Support of Defendantsโ Motion to Dismiss
3:05-cv-1013-DMS-PCL 3

Case 3:05-cv-01013-DMS-PCL     Document 75     Filed 05/04/2007     Page 4 of 10
1 Since late January 2007 -- prior to the filing of the Second Amended Complaint -- and
2 thereafter, the number of ICE detainees housed at SDCFper dayhas fluctuated between 595 to 692.3
3 Declaration of TimothyL.Perry(PerryDecl.)atยถ 17. Plaintiffs, in the Second Amended Complaint,
4 allege that SDCFโs โdesign capacityโ for ICE immigration detainees is 800.  Id. at ยถ 16; Second
5 Amended Complaint at ยถยถ 47, 51. Thus, since late January, 2007, SDCF has been operating below
6 capacity by plaintiffsโ standards, and is not โovercrowded.โ  Perry Decl. at ยถ 18.
7 Furthermore, since late January 2007, there has been no triple-celling of any of the ICE
8 immigration detainees at SDCF, nor has there been any situation akin to โsevere and chronic
9 overcrowding.โ  Id. at ยถยถ 18, 19.  Since late January 2007, no โboatsโ have been used for ICE
10 immigration  detainees, and no immigration pod, administrative segregation unit or holding cell has
11 exceeded capacity.  Id. at ยถ 20, 26.  Finally, no ICE immigration detainees are forced to sleep on
12 โmakeshift bedsโ in the common day rooms at SDCF, though as of May 1, 2007, 11 ICE immigration
13 detainees in the facilitysleptoncommonarea bunk beds inthe dayroom. Id. at ยถยถ 22, 23.  As of May
14 3, 2007, noimmigration detainees were assigned to bunk beds located in day rooms.  Id. at ยถ 23.  As
15 the conditions alleged by plaintiffs do not and have not existed since one month prior to the time the
16 plaintiffsโ Second Amended Complaint was filed, there is no live controversy for the court to resolve.
17 Thus, and as explained more fully below, plaintiffsโ claims are moot, and this case should be
18 dismissed.
19 ARGUMENT
20 I. THIS CASE SHOULD BE DISMISSED AS MOOT SINCE NO โTRIPLE-CELLINGโ
OR OVERCROWDING HAS EXISTED AT ANYTIME SINCE WELL BEFORE THE
21 SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT WAS FILED. 
22 A. The Standard for Mootness
23 Generally, โa case becomes moot โwhen the issues presented areno longer live or the parties
24 lack a legally cognizable interest in the outcome.โโ Murphy v. Hunt, 455 U.S. 478, 481 (1982)
25 (quoting United States Parole Comm'n v. Geraghty, 445 U.S. 388, 396 (1980)); see McBride Cotton
26
27
3There are frequently differences between the counts generated by both ICE and CCA,
28 largely as a result that ICE generates its counts at 6:30 a.m. on a given day, while CCA generates
its count at 11:59 p.m. that night. 
Memorandum of Points and Authorities in Support of Defendantsโ Motion to Dismiss
3:05-cv-1013-DMS-PCL 4

Case 3:05-cv-01013-DMS-PCL     Document 75     Filed 05/04/2007     Page 5 of 10
1 and Cattle Corp. v. Veneman, 290 F.3d 373 (9th Cir. 2002); H.C. ex rel Gordon v. Koppel, 203 F.3d
2 610, 612 (9th Cir. 2000).  Addressing each of these prongs in turn, the present case is moot because
3 the issues presentedare not live and have not been live since before the Second Amended Complaint
4 was filed.  See Herman v. Tidewater Pacific, Inc., 160 F.3d 1239 (9th Cir. 2002). There is no live
5 controversy regarding plaintiffsโ claims, as the alleged practice of โtriple-cellingโ or โsevere and
6 chronic overcrowdingโ do not exist at SDCF.  Perry Decl. at ยถยถ 18, 19.  โGenerally, an action is
7 mooted whentheissuespresentedarenolongerlive and therefore the parties lack a legally cognizable
8 interest for which the courts can grant a remedy.โ Oregon Advocacy Center v. Mink, 322 F.3d 1101
9 (9th Cir. 2003) (citing Alaska Ctr.for Env't v. United States Forest Serv., 189 F.3d 851, 854 (9th Cir.
10 1999)); see also Clark v. City of Lakewood, 259 F.3d 996, 1011 (9th Cir. 2001).  A case becomes
11 moot when interim relieforeventshavedeprivedthecourt of the ability to redress the partyโs injuries.
12 Cook Inlet Treaty Tribes v. Shalala, 166 F.3d 986 (9thCir.1999) (citing United States v. Alder Creek
13 Water Co., 823 F.3d 343, 345 (9th Cir. 1987)). SeealsoDemeryv.Arpaio, 378 F.3d 1020, 1025-26
14 (9th Cir. 2004) (โ[A] suit for injunctive relief is normally moot upon the termination of the conduct
15 at issue . . .โ).  Here, as of late January 2007, SDCF has not โtriple-celledโ any ICE immigration
16 detainees and has not housed more than 692 ICE immigration detainees at one time at the facility.
17 Perry Decl. at ยถยถ17,19.  Also, since late January 2007 no โboatsโ have been used for ICE immigration
18 detainees, and no immigration pod, administrative segregation unit or holding cell has exceeded
19 capacity.  Id. at ยถยถ 20, 26.  Furthermore, since late January 2007 no ICE immigration detainees are
20 forced to sleep on โmakeshift bedsโ in the common day rooms at SDCF, though as of May 1, 2007,
21 11 ICE immigration detainees in the facilitysleptoncommonareabunk beds in the day room.  Id. at
22 ยถยถ 22, 23.  As of May 3, 2007, no immigration detainees were assigned to bunk beds located in day
23 rooms.  Id. at ยถ 23.  As the conditions alleged byplaintiffsin the Second Amended Complaint do not
24 and have not existed since one month prior to the time the Second Amended Complaint was filed,
25 there is no live controversy for the Court to grant plaintiffsโ requests for relief.
26 B. Plaintiffs Fail to Meet the Exception to Mootness
27 The SupremeCourthas โrecognizedan exception to the general rule [of mootness] in cases that
28 are โcapable of repetition, yet evading review.โโ Murphy, 455 U.S. at 482.
Memorandum of Points and Authorities in Support of Defendantsโ Motion to Dismiss
3:05-cv-1013-DMS-PCL 5

Case 3:05-cv-01013-DMS-PCL     Document 75     Filed 05/04/2007     Page 6 of 10
1 [I]n the absence of a class action, the capable of repetition yet evading
review  doctrine  was limited  to  the  situation  where  two  elements
2 combined:  (1) the challenged action was in its duration too short to be
fully litigated prior to its cessation or expiration, and (2) there was a
3 reasonable expectation that the same complaining party would  be
subjected to the same action again.
4
Id.; see also Cole v. Oroville UnionHighSch.Dist., 228F.3d 1092, 1098(9thCir.2000).  โ[A] mere
5
physical or theoretical possibilityโ is insufficient to satisfy the test; [r]ather, . . . there must be a
6
โreasonable expectationโ or a โdemonstrated probabilityโ that the same controversy will recur
7
involving the same complaining party.โ Murphy,455U.S.at 482;see also Demery,378 F.3d at 1027.
8
The Court has โgenerally . . . been unwilling to assume that the party seeking relief will repeat the type
9
of misconduct that would once again place himorher atriskofthat injury.โ Honigv.Doe, 484 U.S.
10
305, 320 (1988) (citing Los Angeles v. Lyons, 461 U.S. 95, 105-106 (1983) (no threat that party
11
seeking injunction barringpolice use of chokeholds would be stopped again for traffic violation or for
12
another offense, or would resist arrest if stopped); Murphy,455U.S. at 484 (noreasonto believe that
13
party challenging denial of pre-trial bail โwill once again be in a position to demand bailโ); O'Shea
14
v. Littleton, 414 U.S.488,497(1974)(unlikely that parties challenging discriminatory bond-setting,
15
sentencing, and jury-fee practices would again violate valid criminal laws). 
16
In Demery v. Arpaio, the Ninth Circuit held that whilea suit for injunctive relief is normally
17
moot upon the termination of the conduct at issue,sucha claim is not moot if there is a likelihood of
18
recurrence.  Demery, 378 F.3d at 1025-26; Fed. TradeComm'nv.AffordableMedia,LLC, 179 F.3d
19
1228, 1238 (9th Cir. 1999) (holding that injunctive relief does not become moot by defendants'
20
voluntary cessation of allegedly wrongful behavior unless it is โabsolutely clear that the allegedly
21
wrongfulbehaviorcannotreasonablybeexpected to recurโ) (quoting Norman-Bloodsaw v. Lawrence
22
Berkeley Laboratory, 135 F.3d 1260, 1274 (9thCir.1998)); InDemery,the NinthCircuit determined
23
that the plaintiffsโ lawsuit seeking a preliminaryinjunction barring the use of โwebcamsโin a prison
24
was not moot, based on the defendant sheriffโs โunequivocalโ representations and actions indicating
25
that he would reactivate the webcams if the injunction was vacated.  Demery, 378 F.3d at 1026.  In
26
stark contrast, the defendants in the present case explicitlyaffirm thatthe allegedwrongful behavior
27
is not reasonablyexpected to recur.  See Perry Decl. at ยถยถ 21, 24-26.  Defendants do not reasonably
28
expect to engage in the practice of triple-celling the immigration detainees at SDCF and do not
Memorandum of Points and Authorities in Support of Defendantsโ Motion to Dismiss
3:05-cv-1013-DMS-PCL 6

Case 3:05-cv-01013-DMS-PCL     Document 75     Filed 05/04/2007     Page 7 of 10
1 reasonably expect to significantly increase operation above current levels.  Id. at ยถ 21.  This
2 expectation is reasonable based on the fact that much of the triple-celling alleged in the Second
3 Amended Complaint was the immediate result of a loss of bed space due to San Diego Countyโs
4 requiring the facility to provide the county with 200 beds.  Id. at ยถ 14.  As a result, CCA needed to find
5 a method of housingthe immigration detainee population affected by this change.  Id.  There is also
6 no reasonable expectation that โboatsโ will be used for ICE immigration detainees at SDCF, or that
7 any immigration pod, administrative segregation unit or holding cell will exceed ICEโscapacity. Id.
8 at ยถ 21, 26. Finally,thereisnoreasonable expectation that ICE immigration detainees will be forced
9 to sleep on โmakeshift bedsโ in the common day rooms at SDCF.  Id. at ยถ 24.
10 Thus, for all of the reasons mentioned above, there is no โreasonable expectationโ or
11 โdemonstrated probabilityโ that meets the standard for plaintiffsโ claims to beconsidered capable of
12 repetition.4  There is no longer a โliveโ controversy affecting plaintiffs, and plaintiffs lack a legally
13 cognizable interest in the outcome.  Plaintiffsโ claims are moot, and this case should be dismissed.
